summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2020 between FBI Litigation Support Unit personnel and a U.S. Attorney's Office (likely SDNY) regarding the technical review and transfer of media files (audio, video) related to the Epstein investigation. It references specific file numbers, technical issues with audio codecs, and lists media items including grand jury testimony and depositions.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Identified as the source from whom a 2010 video deposition of Jeffrey Epstein was received.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the subject of a 2010 video deposition received from attorney Brad Edwards.

connections.description: Brad Edwards is identified as the attorney who provided a video deposition of Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI.

events.title: Grand Jury Testimony Audio Files
events.description: 48 audio files of grand jury testimony were recorded. The media was received from the PB (Palm Beach) State Attorney's Office.

events.title: FBI and AUSA Interview
events.description: An interview was conducted by FBI Special Agents and an Assistant U.S. Attorney. The specific subject is redacted.

events.title: Deposition of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: A video deposition of Jeffrey Epstein was taken (case: IN vs. Jeffrey Epstein). The media was received from attorney Brad Edwards.

keyFacts: The FBI Litigation Support Unit was coordinating with a U.S. Attorney's Office in October 2020 regarding media files from the Epstein investigation, indicating ongoing discovery or review work years after Epstein's death.
Technical issues were encountered with 48 grand jury testimony audio files from July 2006 due to a 'codec problem,' potentially caused by an error when the AUSA's office exported the media.
Specific media items listed include: 48 grand jury audio files (2006), an FBI/AUSA interview audio (2007), and a video deposition of Jeffrey Epstein (2010).
The correspondence references file number 31E-MM-108062, which appears to be a central FBI case file for the Epstein investigation.
Multiple names and email addresses are redacted, indicating the involvement of FBI personnel, AUSAs, and possibly other witnesses or subjects whose identities are protected.
